Description: THE NATURAL RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP PROGRAM IS THE PRINCIPLE MEANS THROUGH WHICH THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE (NPS) EVALUATES AND IMPROVES THE HEALTH OF WATERSHEDS, LANDSCAPES, AND MARINE AND COASTAL RESOURCES, SUSTAINS BIOLOGICAL COMMUNITIES ON THE LANDS AND WATERS IN PARKS, AND ACTIVELY ENDEAVORS TO IMPROVE THE RESILIENCY OF THESE NATURAL RESOURCES AND ADAPT THEM TO THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE. TO CARRY OUT AND FURTHER THIS STEWARDSHIP RESPONSIBILITY, NPS IMPLEMENTS PROGRAMS THAT ENCOMPASS A BROAD RANGE OF RESEARCH, OPERATIONAL, AND EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES BY UTILIZING PARK PERSONNEL AND CONTRACTOR SUPPORT OR PAGE 4 OF 4 COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS. INVASIVE ZEBRA MUSSELS REPRESENT A SIGNIFICANT THREAT TO THE ECOSYSTEM OF THE ST. CROIX RIVER AND ITS WATERSHED. EDUCATING BOATERS AND WATER RECREATORS IS ESSENTIAL TO CONTROL FURTHER INFESTATION WITHIN THE ST. CROIX RIVER WATERSHED AND TO PREVENT THEIR SPREAD INTO NEARBY WATERBODIES. NPS STAFF WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH THEIR OFFICIAL NON-PROFIT PARTNER AND VOLUNTEER GROUPS TO BUILD PROGRAMMING AND DELIVER FOCUSED OUTREACH THAT WILL TARGET ZEBRA MUSSEL PREVENTION, SUPPORT EARLY DETECTION AND RAPID RESPONSE (EDRR) PROTOCOLS, AND ENHANCE AIS EDUCATION OUTREACH AND AWARENESS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE THE PURCHASE OF A DECONTAMINATION UNIT TO BE PLACED AT HIGH TRAFFIC LANDINGS.BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

THE NATURAL RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP PROGRAM IS THE PRINCIPLE MEANS THROUGH WHICH THE NPS EVALUATES AND IMPROVES THE HEALTH OF WATERSHEDS, LANDSCAPES, AND MARINE AND COASTAL RESOURCES, SUSTAINS BIOLOGICAL COMMUNITIES ON THE LANDS AND WATERS IN PARKS, AND ACTIVELY ENDEAVORS TO IMPROVE THE RESILIENCY OF THESE NATURAL RESOURCES AND ADAPT THEM TO THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE. THIS PROJECT WILL PRIMARILY FOCUS ON COAL CREEK, A TRIBUTARY OF THE YUKON RIVER NEAR SLAVENS ROADHOUSE IN YUKON-CHARLEY RIVERS NATIONAL PRESERVE (YUCH).  THE MAIN OBJECTIVES ARE TO CREATE A RESTORATION PLAN FOR COAL CREEK THAT COMBINES EXPERTISE PROVIDED BY THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AND SALCHA-DELTA SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT, AND TO RESTORE RIPARIAN HABITAT USING NATURAL STREAM DESIGN TECHNIQUES THAT WILL PROTECT THE INFRASTRUCTURE OF THE AREA AND IMPROVE FISH HABITAT.  AS FUNDING PERMITS, THIS PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT THE PLAN AND MONITOR THE PLANS IMPACT ON THE AREA TO MAKE SURE THAT THE RESTORATION IS MEETING THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT. 2023 SUMMERSALCHA-DELTA SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT, AND THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE WILL WORK JOINTLY TO HOLD STREAM RESTORATION DESIGN WORKSHOPS TO PLAN BASE MAPPING NEEDS AND DEVELOP ROUGH DESIGNS WITHIN THE CONSTRAINTS. SALCHA-DELTA SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT, AND THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE WILL WORK JOINTLY TO START DRAFTING A CONCEPTUAL DESIGN AND START THE SITE ASSESSMENTS AND BASE MAPPING. SALCHA-DELTA SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT AND NATIONAL PARK SERVICE WILL SEEK ADDITIONAL LOCAL AND TRIBAL PARTNERS TO PARTICIPATE IN SUBSEQUENT PHASES OF WORK, INCLUDING YOUTH TRAINING COMPONENTS AND PUBLIC COMMUNICATION, OUTREACH AND EDUCATION COMPONENTS.2023-2024 WINTERSALCHA-DELTA SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT, AND THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE WILL HOLD WORKSHOPS TO DEVELOP 20  STREAM DESIGN PLANS. ADDITIONAL FIELD DATA NEEDS WILL BE DISCUSSED AND PLANNED DURING THESE WORKSHOPS. STREAM REACH RESTORATION PRIORITIES WILL BE CREATED.2024SALCHA-DELTA SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT, AND THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE WILL WORK JOINTLY TO COMPLETE THE BASE MAPPING, FIELD DATA, AND MONITORING NEEDS TO COMPLETE 90  LEVEL DESIGN PLAN.2025SALCHA-DELTA SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT, AND THE NPS WILL WORK JOINTLY TO EXECUTE THE STREAM RESTORATION, REVEGETATION, AND MONITORING.2025-2028SALCHA-DELTA SOIL AND WATER CONSERVATION DISTRICT AND THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE WILL CONTINUE TO WORK TOGETHER TO MONITOR THE RESTORATION AND CHECK FOR INVASIVE SPECIES. ADDITIONAL RESTORATION WORK ON OTHER PRIORITY REACHES MAY BE EXECUTED DEPENDING ON AVAILABLE FUNDING.BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE LANDOWNERS, SCHOOLS, LIBRARIES, COMMUNITIES, VILLAGES, TRIBAL GOVERNMENTS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

AMERICAN FORESTS AND SEKI WILL WORK TOGETHER TO CARRY OUT INFORMATION GATHERING, ASSESSMENT, PLANNING, STRATEGIES, AND IMPLEMENTATION IN SERVICE TO CLIMATE-SMART REFORESTATION WHERE NEEDED IN SEQUOIA AND KINGS CANYON NATIONAL PARKS. THE NATURAL RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP PROGRAM IS THE PRINCIPLE MEANS THROUGH WHICH THE NPS EVALUATES AND IMPROVES THE HEALTH OF WATERSHEDS, LANDSCAPES, AND MARINE AND COASTAL RESOURCES, SUSTAINS BIOLOGICAL COMMUNITIES ON THE LANDS AND WATERS IN PARKS, AND ACTIVELY ENDEAVORS TO IMPROVE THE RESILIENCY OF THESE NATURAL RESOURCES AND ADAPT THEM TO THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE. FOR THIS PROJECT, THE UNIVERSITY OF HOUSTON, NATIONAL CENTER FOR AIRBORNE LASER MAPPING WILL COLLECT HIGH-RESOLUTION (1.0-M SPATIAL RESOLUTION OR LESS) TOPOGRAPHIC DATA AND CONDUCT STATE OF THE ART POST-PROCESSING OF THESE DATA FOR SELECT SITES IN AND IMMEDIATELY ADJACENT TO DENALI NATIONAL PARK   PRESERVE. THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, FEDERAL HIGHWAYS ADMINISTRATION, ACADEMIC, AND CONTRACTOR STAFF WILL USE THESE DATA, METHODS, AND TOOLS TO INFORM GEOHAZARD, ABANDONED MINE LANDS (AML), AND A WIDE RANGE OF OTHER ASSESSMENTS. DENALI NATIONAL PARK   PRESERVE SCIENTISTS WILL DETERMINE THE CRITICAL AREAS OF INTEREST, PROVIDE FIELD SUPPORT, ESTABLISH GROUND CONTROL, VALIDATE DATASETS, EVALUATE PROCESSING METHODS, ENGAGE UNIVERSITY OF HOUSTON STUDENTS, AND CONTRIBUTE TOPOGRAPHIC DATASETS FOR BROAD USAGE FOR ACADEMIA, GOVERNMENT, CONTRACTORS, AND THE PUBLIC.  DENALI NATIONAL PARK   PRESERVE AND NATIONAL CENTER FOR AIRBORNE LASER MAPPING WILL WORK COLLABORATIVELY AFTER DATA PROCESSING TO IDENTIFY AREAS OF LANDSLIDE HAZARD, BY COMBINING THEIR EXPERTISE IN LANDSLIDE HAZARD ASSESSMENT AND IDENTIFICATION AND ADVANCED 3D DATA PROCESSING, VISUALIZATION, AND ANALYSIS. THE WORK WILL RESULT IN JOINT PRESENTATIONS AT PROFESSIONAL CONFERENCES.BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE UNIVERSITY OF HOUSTON STUDENTS, ACADEMIA, GOVERNMENT, CONTRACTORS, AND THE PUBLIC.

THE FEDERAL LEGISLATION IN 1964 AND 1970 ESTABLISHED THE ICE AGE NATIONAL SCIENTIFIC RESERVE IN WISCONSIN AS A PARTNERSHIP PROJECT BETWEEN THE NPS AND WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES (WDNR). ITS PURPOSE IS TO ASSURE PROTECTION, PRESERVATION, AND INTERPRETATION OF THE NATIONALLY SIGNIFICANT VALUES OF WISCONSIN CONTINENTAL GLACIATION. AN IMPORTANT FACET OF THE RESERVE IS THE ANNUAL FUNDING PROVIDED BY THE NPS TO THE WDNR TO DEVELOP AND OPERATE THE RESERVE FOR ALL AMERICANS. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

THIS PROJECT PROVIDES OPPORTUNITIES FOR NPS AND THE RECIPIENT TO WORK TOGETHER ON GEOSCIENCE PROJECTS AND INITIATIVES WITH COMMON GOALS. THE NPS PALEONTOLOGY PROGRAM PROVIDES TECHNICAL SUPPORT TO PARKS THROUGHOUT THE NPS INVOLVING A VARIETY OF PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCES ISSUES AND NEEDS. IN MANY INSTANCES THE TECHNICAL SUPPORT TO PARKS IS TIED TO MANDATES IDENTIFIED IN THE PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCES PRESERVATION ACT, OTHER LAWS, NPS MANAGEMENT POLICIES OR NPS DIRECTORS ORDER  77. THIS SUPPORT INCLUDES (BUT IS NOT LIMITED TO): PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCE INVENTORY, MONITORING, RESEARCH, CURATION, EDUCATION   INTERPRETATION, PROTECTION, PLANNING, AND TRAINING. THIS SUPPORT IS SOMETIMES ACHIEVED THROUGH PARTNERSHIPS AND AGREEMENTS WITH THE SCIENTIFIC COMMUNITY AND OTHER AGENCIES WITH STAFF QUALIFIED TO SUPPORT THE PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCE NEEDS IDENTIFIED IN THE TECHNICAL SUPPORT. IN COLLABORATION WITH THE NPS PALEONTOLOGY PROGRAM AND THE STAFF AT BRYCE CANYON NATIONAL PARK, THE RECIPIENT WILL INITIATE A FIELD-BASED, PRE-EXCAVATION PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCE ASSESSMENT OF A CRETACEOUS DINOSAUR LOCALITY AT BRYCE CANYON NATIONAL PARK, UTAH. THIS ASSESSMENT WILL GATHER INFORMATION PERTAINING TO THE NATURE AND CONDITION OF THE FOSSIL SPECIMEN AND ASSOCIATED GEOLOGIC STRATA.  PARTIES WILL WORK TOGETHER TO PLAN AND IMPLEMENT A PRE-EXCAVATION FIELD ASSESSMENT OF THE FOSSIL DINOSAUR LOCALITY AT BRYCE CANYON NATIONAL PARK IN ORDER TO ASSESS THE NEEDS AND FEASIBILITY OF COORDINATING A SUCCESSFUL EXCAVATION OF THE FOSSIL REMAINS. THE RECIPIENT WILL PREPARE A FOSSIL EXCAVATION PLAN WITH RECOMMENDATIONS TO HELP INFORM THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE STAFF ON IMPORTANT AND RELEVANT CONSIDERATIONS FOR PLANNING AND DECISION-MAKING. THE REPORT SHOULD ADDRESS WHETHER FOSSIL EXCAVATION IS WARRANTED AND FEASIBLE, THE LOCALITY-SPECIFIC METHODS WHICH SHOULD BE EMPLOYED IF EXCAVATION IS APPROVED, AND GUIDANCE ON PROFESSIONAL TECHNIQUES FOR FOSSIL COLLECTION AND POST-EXCAVATION RESTORATION   STABILIZATION.BY PARTNERING WITH THE RECIPIENT, THE NPS WILL BE ABLE TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THE SCOPE, SIGNIFICANCE, DISTRIBUTION AND MANAGEMENT ISSUES ASSOCIATED WITH NON-RENEWABLE PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCES AT BRYCE CANYON NATIONAL PARK. THE PROPOSED PALEONTOLOGICAL RESOURCE ASSESSMENT WILL INFORM PARK MANAGEMENT ABOUT THE BEST PRACTICES AND PLANNING FOR THE FIELD EXCAVATION OF A RECENTLY DISCOVERED DINOSAUR SKELETON. THIS INFORMATION WILL ENHANCE OPPORTUNITIES FOR SCIENCE, RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, RESOURCE PROTECTION, AND PUBLIC EDUCATION.

THE NATURAL RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP PROGRAM IS THE PRINCIPLE MEANS THROUGH WHICH THE NATIONALPARK SERVICE (NPS) EVALUATES AND IMPROVES THE HEALTH OF WATERSHEDS, LANDSCAPES, AND MARINE AND COASTALRESOURCES, SUSTAINS BIOLOGICAL COMMUNITIES ON THE LANDS AND WATERS IN PARKS, AND ACTIVELY ENDEAVORS TOIMPROVE THE RESILIENCY OF THESE NATURAL RESOURCES AND ADAPT THEM TO THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE. TO CARRYOUT AND FURTHER THIS STEWARDSHIP RESPONSIBILITY, NPS IMPLEMENTS PROGRAMS THAT ENCOMPASS A BROAD RANGEOF RESEARCH, OPERATIONAL, AND EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES BY UTILIZING PARK PERSONNEL AND CONTRACTOR SUPPORT ORCOOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS. THE SCIENTISTS IN PARKS PROGRAM PROVIDES OPPORTUNITIES FOR PARTICIPANTS TO MEET NATURAL RESOURCE MANAGEMENT NEEDS IN NATIONAL PARK UNITS, ADVANCE THEIR ACADEMIC AND PROFESSIONAL GOALS, INCREASE DIVERSITY AND INCLUSION WITHIN NATURAL RESOURCE FIELDS OF THE NPS, AND FOSTER LIFE-LONG CONNECTIONS TO NATIONAL PARK RESOURCES. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE GENERAL PUBLIC.

THE NATURAL RESOURCE STEWARDSHIP PROGRAM IS THE PRINCIPLE MEANS THROUGH WHICH THE NATIONALPARK SERVICE  NPS  EVALUATES AND IMPROVES THE HEALTH OF WATERSHEDS, LANDSCAPES, AND MARINE AND COASTALRESOURCES, SUSTAINS BIOLOGICAL COMMUNITIES ON THE LANDS AND WATERS IN PARKS, AND ACTIVELY ENDEAVORS TOIMPROVE THE RESILIENCY OF THESE NATURAL RESOURCES AND ADAPT THEM TO THE EFFECTS OF CLIMATE CHANGE  TO CARRYOUT AND FURTHER THIS STEWARDSHIP RESPONSIBILITY, NPS IMPLEMENTS PROGRAMS THAT ENCOMPASS A BROAD RANGEOF RESEARCH, OPERATIONAL, AND EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES BY UTILIZING PARK PERSONNEL AND COOPERATIVE AGREEMENTS  THE PROPOSED EFFORT IS IN RESPONSE TO THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE S  NPS  GROWING INTEREST IN USING REMOTE SENSING TO FACILITATE THE MONITORING OF SHORELINE CHANGE IN ITS COASTAL UNITS  RELIABLE MONITORING OF SHORELINE CHANGE IS IMPORTANT FOR EVALUATING COASTAL EXPOSURE TO EROSION HAZARDS AND FOR UNDERSTANDING THE VULNERABILITY OF SENSITIVE NATURAL RESOURCES, CULTURAL AND HISTORICAL RESOURCES, ESSENTIAL INFRASTRUCTURE, AND SAFE STAFF AND VISITOR ACCESS   BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THEGENERAL PUBLIC

LANDS  THE FIRST GOAL OF THE MONITORING PROGRAM IS TO DETERMINE THE PRESENCE ABSENCE, OR OCCUPANCY, OF NSO WITHIN EACH TERRITORY FOR THE YEAR  PRECISE LOCATIONS OF NSO OBSERVED WITHIN THE TERRITORIES PURPOSE OF AWARD  SUMMARY OF THE GOALS AND OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT   THIS PROJECT RESTORES CRITICAL HABITAT FOR THE GOLDEN WINGED WARBLER  GWWA  IN PRIORITY AREAS ALONG THE APPALACHIAN NATIONAL SCENIC TRAIL  THE WORK FOCUSES ON INCREASING GWWA POPULATIONS BY IMPROVING THE QUALITY AND INCREASING THE QUANTITY OF BREEDING HABITAT AT FOCAL AREAS WHERE PREVIOUSLY SUITABLE AREAS HAVE  AGED OUT , NO LONGER PROVIDING THE CHARACTERISTICS NEEDED BY THE SPECIES  FIVE ACRE EDGE SECTIONS OF EXISTING EARLY SUCCESSIONAL HABITAT  ESH  SITES WILL BE TREATED TO THE SPECIFICATIONS OUTLINED IN THE GUIDELINE BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR GOLDEN WINGED WARBLER HABITATS IN THE APPALACHIAN REGION RESULTING IN AN ADDITIONAL ESTIMATED 7 15 BREEDING BIRD PAIRS AS WELL AS OTHER SPECIES THAT FAVOR ESH ENVIRONMENTS SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES  RESTORATION WORK WILL BE PERFORMED ADJACENT TO EXISTING ESH ON FIVE ACRE EDGE SECTIONS TOTALING APPROXIMATELY 70 ACRES  HERBICIDE APPLICATION, MECHANICAL CLEARING, MANUAL BRUSHING, NATIVE SEEDING, AND FOLLOW UP MONITORING WILL TAKE PLACE ACCORDING TO ESTABLISHED GUIDELINES PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES  IN THE COURSE OF THIS PROJECT, APPROXIMATELY 70 ACRES OF ESH WILL BE RESTORED TO CONDITIONS SUITABLE FOR GWWA, WHICH IS ESTIMATED TO SUPPORT AN ADDITIONAL ESTIMATED 7 15 BREEDING BIRD PAIRS  IMPROVEMENTS TO GWWA HABITAT WILL ALSO BENEFIT A WIDE RANGE OF ASSOCIATED BIRD SPECIES AND POLLINATORS  UPON PROJECT COMPLETION, TREATED AREAS WILL BE DESIGNATED AS ESSENTIAL GWWA HABITAT AND INCORPORATED INTO AN EXISTING LONG TERM MONITORING AND MAINTENANCE PROGRAM ADMINISTERED AND OPERATED BY APPALACHIAN TRAIL COOPERATIVE MANAGEMENT PARTNERS BENEFICIARIES  GWWA AND OTHER SENSITIVE SPECIES  BIRDERS AND OTHER PUBLIC LANDS VISITORS

PROJECT STATEMENT   THE NATIONAL TRAILS PROGRAM AT MIDDLE TENNESSEE STATE UNIVERSITY  MTSU  HAS BEEN ENGAGED IN COMMUNITY OUTREACH, PRESERVATION, AND RESEARCH ON THE TRAIL OF TEARS NATIONAL HISTORIC TRAIL  TRTE  FOR OVER TEN YEARS  MTSU PROPOSES TO APPLY THE PROTOCOL BEING DEVELOPED BY THE NATIONAL TRAILS OFFICE TO SITES AND SEGMENTS ALONG THE TRTE  IN DOING SO THE NATIONAL TRAILS OFFICE, MTSU, AND LOCAL TRAIL PARTNERS WILL COLLABORATE TO REFINE THE PROTOCOL FOR USE ALONG THE TRTE  PERFORMANCE GOALS   THE GOALS OF THIS PROJECT ARE THREEFOLD  1  INCREASE AND ENHANCE KNOWLEDGE OF SITES AND SEGMENTS THAT ARE IMPORTANT TO THE VISITOR EXPERIENCE ALONG  THE TRTE, 2  EXPLORE HOW THE DOCUMENTATION PROTOCOL MIGHT BE APPLIED TO THE TRTE, AND 3  ENHANCE THE COLLABORATIVE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN MTSU, THE PUBLIC, AND THE NATIONAL TRAILS OFFICE FOR THE  PRESERVATION OF THE TRTE PERFORMANCE OBJECTIVES   USING THE PROTOCOL IN DEVELOPMENT BY THE NATIONAL TRAILS OFFICE, MTSU WILL DOCUMENT AND EVALUATE UP TO 30 SITES ALONG OR ASSOCIATED WITH TRTE THROUGHOUT TENNESSEE AND KENTUCKY  DURING THE FIELDWORK PHASE MTSU WILL ENGAGE LOCAL TRAIL PARTNERS IN THE SITE EVALUATION PROCESS  BEFORE, DURING, AND AFTER FIELD WORK MTSU WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE NATIONAL TRAILS OFFICE TO REVIEW AND REFINE THE PROTOCOL FOR SPECIFIC APPLICATION TO THE TRTE CFDA  15 945 COOPERATIVE RESEARCH AND  TRAINING PROGRAMS   RESOURCES OF THE NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM

SUMMARY OF PROJECT SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES: RECRUIT, TRAIN, MENTOR AND PROVIDE CAREER COUNSELING IN PUBLIC LANDS NATURAL RESOURCE CONSERVATION FOR THREE LOCAL CAMP MENTORS. EMPLOY THE MENTORS DURING SUMMER CAMPS AS MENTORS AND GUIDES TO YOUNGER YOUTH ENROLLED AS COHORTS. LOCAL CAMP MENTORS WILL RECEIVE AT LEAST TWO WEEKS OF TRAINING PRIOR TO ENGAGEMENT WITH THE ENROLLEE COHORT GROUP IN THE SUMMER 2022 AND RECEIVE REFRESHER TRAINING PRIOR TO THE 10-WEEK SUMMER 2023 SESSION. ENGAGE LOCAL CAMP MENTORS IN THE AFTER-ACTION REVIEWS OF THE ONE-WEEK SUMMER COHORT SESSION AND ENGAGE MEMBERS IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF FUTURE CURRICULUM. ESTABLISH AND CONDUCT A ONE-WEEK PILOT CONSERVATION CAMP FOR 25 YOUTH AGED 12-15 DURING THE SUMMER 2022. GAIN VALUABLE AND DIVERSE CURRICULUM DEVELOPMENT INPUT FROM BOTH CAMP MENTORS AND THE ENROLLED CAMP YOUTH FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF A 10-WEEK SUMMER CAMP FOR A COHORT OF 25 LOCAL YOUTH AGED 12-15 DURING THE SUMMER 2023. PERFORMANCE GOALS INCLUDING MILESTONES AND EXPECTED OUTCOMES: 1) CREATE A PROGRAM OF CONSERVATION EDUCATION AND TRADITIONAL LOCAL KNOWLEDGE FOR THE ENGAGEMENT OF YOUTH AGED 12 TO 15 DURING THE SUMMER MONTHS, PROVIDING OPPORTUNITIES TO PARTICIPATE IN USING GAINED KNOWLEDGE ON APPROPRIATE CONSERVATION PROJECTS ON ELIGIBLE SERVICE LAND. 2) EMPLOY 3 YOUNG ADULTS (RECENT HIGH SCHOOL GRADUATES AND/OR COLLEGE-AGED YOUNG ADULTS) FROM THE COMMUNITY TO BE YOUTH MENTORS TO GAIN PROFESSIONAL EXPERIENCE, BE EXPOSED TO CAREER OPPORTUNITIES ON PUBLIC LANDS, AND PASS KNOWLEDGE ON TO A YOUNGER GENERATION. BENEFICIARIES: BENEFICIARIES ARE THE 25 PERSON YOUTH COHORT WHO LEARN CONSERVATION TECHNIQUES ON PUBLIC LANDS, COHORT MENTORS WHO WILL LEARN VALUABLE LEADERSHIP AND COUNSELING SKILLS WHILE WORKING WITH YOUNGER AGED YOUTH AS WELL AS BE EXPOSED TO CAREERS IN LAND AND RESOURCE MANAGEMENT, THE PROJECT PUBLIC LANDS, AND BOTH COMMUNITY RESIDENTS AND VISITORS WHO TRAVERS THE PUBLIC LANDS.

PROJECT STATEMENT - THREE AMERICORPS MEMBERS WILL BE WORKING IN THE DIVISION OF RESOURCE EDUCATION TO PROVIDE EDUCATION AND VISITOR SERVICES TO BOTH YOUTH GROUPS AND THE VISITING PUBLIC. EACH INTERN WILL SUPPORT IN GREAT SMOKY MOUNTAIN NATIONAL PARK (GRSM)'S EFFORTS TO CREATE OPPORTUNITIES FOR CONNECTION TO GRSM AND ITS RESOURCES THROUGH SERVICES AND PROGRAMS TO THE VISITING PUBLIC AND SCHOOL GROUPS FROM NEIGHBORING PARK COMMUNITIES. THE PROGRAMS PRESENTED BY THE SERVING MEMBERS WILL BE ON GRSM'S NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES. THE MEMBERS MAY PERFORM BOTH FORMAL AND INFORMAL PROGRAMS INCLUDING EXPLORATORY WALKS, JR RANGER PROGRAMS, AND SCHOOL-BASED EDUCATION PROGRAMS. THE MEMBERS WILL ALSO PERFORM INFORMAL ROVING INTERPRETATION AT SEVERAL SITES WITHIN GRSM.PERFORMANCE GOALS - TO PROVIDE AND FACILITATE MEMORABLE AND MEANINGFUL CONNECTION TO PARK RESOURCES TO YOUTH GROUPS AND THE PUBLIC. TO FOSTER DEVELOPMENT OF A PERSONAL STEWARDSHIP ETHIC AND BROADEN PUBLIC SUPPORT FOR PRESERVING PARK RESOURCES.PERFORMANCE OBJECTIVES - THE PRIMARY OBJECTIVE OF THE POSITION IS TO PROVIDE HIGH QUALITY INTERPRETIVE SERVICES THROUGH CONTACTS AT THE VISITOR INFORMATION DESK, FORMAL AND INFORMAL INTERPRETIVE PROGRAMS, AND SPECIAL EVENT MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE.CFDA 15.931

THE C&O CANAL NHP PROVIDES HABITAT FOR OVER 200 RARE, THREATENED, AND ENDANGERED PLANT SPECIES AND MULTIPLE GLOBALLY RARE COMMUNITIES. HOWEVER, MANY RARE PLANT POPULATIONS ARE AT RISK FROM HABITAT LOSS AND FRAGMENTATION AND ARE BEING PUSHED TOWARD EXTINCTION BECAUSE OF THE PARK'S MOSTLY NARROW GEOGRAPHIC WIDTH AND STRESSORS FROM THE SURROUNDING URBAN AND SUBURBAN DEVELOPMENT, MORE THAN 5 MILLION VISITORS ANNUALLY, AND A CONTINUAL BARRAGE OF INVASIVE SPECIES. MOVING BEYOND ONLY CONTROLLING NONNATIVE INVASIVES, THE PARK NEEDS TO ACTIVELY MANAGE AND EXPAND EFFORTS TO IMPROVE THE RESILIENCE OF RARE PLANT POPULATIONS THROUGH AUGMENTATION. THROUGH THIS WORK, THE PARK AND PARTNER WILL INCREASE THE VIABILITY OF RARE PLANT POPULATIONS IN THE LONG TERM BY (1) COLLECTING FRUIT/SEED FROM RARE, THREATENED, AND ENDANGERED PLANTS WITHIN THE PARK, (2) PROPAGATING THEM EX SITU USING APPROPRIATE AND RESEARCHED HORTICULTURAL PROCEDURES IN PARTNER GREENHOUSE FACILITIES, AND (3) OUTPLANTING INDIVIDUALS INTO CAREFULLY PREPARED SITES. THIS PROJECT WILL AID THE PARK IN FACILITATING AND ENSURING LONG-TERM SURVIVAL OF RARE, THREATENED, AND ENDANGERED PLANT SPECIES. POPULATION SIZE AND DENSITY OF DOZENS OF RARE PLANTS WILL INCREASE UPON COMPLETION OF THE TASKS ASSOCIATED WITH THIS AGREEMENT. WE WILL CONDUCT LITERATURE REVIEWS AND ESTABLISH COLLECTION AND PROPAGATION PROTOCOLS FOR NUMEROUS RARE PLANT SPECIES. PROJECT OUTCOMES WILL ALLOW FOR THE PARK TO IMMEDIATELY ADDRESS LOW POPULATION SIZES AND WILL ALSO FACILITATE FUTURE PROPAGATION AND POPULATION AUGMENTATION WORK.

THE OBJECTIVES AND OUTCOMES FOR EACH PROJECT ARE DEFINED BY THE BENEFITING NPS UNIT THAT HOSTS THE INTERN.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT AND ENHANCE RIPARIAN HABITAT IN THE PRAIRIE CREEK WATERSHED AND MAINSTEM OF PRAIRIE CREEK IN REDWOOD NATIONAL AND STATE PARKS. THIS PROJECT IS ONE PART OF MANY PROJECTS BEING UNDERTAKEN BY THE REDWOODS RISING COLLABORATIVE. REDWOODS RISING IS AN ONGOING PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN SAVE THE REDWOODS LEAGUE, THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE, THE YUROK TRIBE, AND THE CALIFORNIA STATE PARKS, PARTNERING TO IMPLEMENT A MULTI-YEAR WATERSHED RESTORATION EFFORT ACROSS 43,000 ACRES OF REDWOOD NATIONAL AND STATE PARKS WATERSHEDS. SUCCESSFUL COMPLETION OF THIS PHASE OF THE PROJECT WILL BE THE DELIVERY OF 1,500 HEALTHY, 2- TO 3-YEAR-OLD SEEDLING TREES. BENEFICIARES ARE SAVE THE REDWOODS LEAGUE.

SIERRA INSTITUTE FOR COMMUNITY AND ENVIRONMENT TECHNICIANS WILL ASSIST LASSEN VOLCANIC NATIONAL PARK WITH CONSERVATION PROJECTS, INCLUDING SURVEYS THAT SUPPORT FOREST RESTORATION ACTIVITIES, RARE AND INVASIVE PLANT SURVEYS AND CONTROL, WILDLIFE, AND CULTURAL STUDIES TO SUPPORT SEVERAL PARK RESTORATION PROJECTS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE RESTORATION OF NATIONAL PARK SERVICE AND ADJACENT LANDS FOLLOWING THE DIXIE FIRE BY COMPLETING PRIORITY SURVEYS TO ASSESS IMPACTS OF THE FIRE AND POTENTIAL RESTORATION OPERATIONS, WHILE EXPANDING THE KNOWLEDGE BASE OF PARK RESOURCES AND HOW THEY ARE NATURALLY RESPONDING TO THE DIXIE FIRE. TECHNICIANS WILL PARTICIPATE IN ARCHEOLOGICAL SURVEYS, WILDLIFE SURVEYS, INVASIVE PLANT SURVEYS, SEED COLLECTION FOR FUTURE RESTORATION PROJECTS, RESTORATION TREATMENTS AND MONITORING IN PARK CAMPGROUNDS, AND INVASIVE PLANT MANAGEMENT AND RESTORATION. THE TECHNICIANS WILL ALSO WORK ON PROJECTS ON ADJACENT JURISDICTIONS TO ADVANCE LARGE LANDSCAPE RESTORATION EFFORTS SUCH AS THE WEST LASSEN HEADWATERS PROJECT. BENEFICIARIES INCLUDE THE YOUNG ADULTS SUPPORTED BY THIS PROJECT, THE PUBLIC, THE BOTANICAL RESEARCH COMMUNITY, AND RURAL COMMUNITIES.

THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE MANAGES 88 OCEAN, COASTAL, AND GREAT LAKES PARK UNITS THAT ENCOMPASS A BROAD RANGE OF IMPORTANT HABITATS THAT ARE VULNERABLE TO OIL SPILLS. THE QUICK CLEAN-UP OF AN OIL SPILL IS IMPORTANT TO MINIMIZE DAMAGE TO THE ECOSYSTEM. OIL SPILL PREPAREDNESS AND RESPONSE IS CRITICAL TO PROTECTING PARK NATURAL AND CULTURAL RESOURCES AND HAS BEEN IDENTIFIED AS A PRIORITY. MANY OF THE TASKS ASSOCIATED WITH GUIDING OIL SPILL PREPAREDNESS AND RESPONSE EFFORTS WITHIN NPS ARE A PERFECT FIT FOR ASSISTANCE FROM AN INTERN. THE OPPORTUNITY WILL ALLOW THE INTERN TO EXPAND THEIR SKILL SET AND ENCOURAGE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT WHILE CONTRIBUTING TO THESE PRIORITY PROJECTS.THE INTERN WILL WORK WITH AN NPS MENTOR TO HELP INFORM OIL SPILL PREPAREDNESS AND RESPONSE BY COMPILING AND SYNTHESIZING INFORMATION, CONDUCTING GAP ANALYSES, AND PROVIDING RECOMMENDATIONS. THE FINAL PRODUCTS INCLUDE A DATABASE, REPORT, INTERACTIVE MAP, TOOLKIT AND/OR PRESENTATIONS.
